fullText: This new production of 'The Gershwins' Porgy and Bess' honors both the glorious music and the problematic nature of its source, creating a version that feels both authentic and contemporary.
dtliExcerpt: This new production of 'The Gershwins' Porgy and Bess' honors both the glorious music and the problematic nature of its source, creating a version that feels both authentic and contemporary.
bwwExcerpt: But there’s a catch. Ms. McDonald’s Bess is — in a word — great; the show in which she appears is, at best, just pretty good. She and (the robust and intimidating) Mr. Boykin inhabit a world of exalted, dangerous passions that is separate from the rest of the denizens of Catfish Row...The enduring and magnetic appeal of Gershwin’s score is undeniable. It is pleasantly sung and played here. (William David Brohn and Christopher Jahnke did the new orchestrations; Constantine Kitsopolous is the musi

llmScore.reasoning: [ensemble-unanimous] | All 4 models agree: Positive | Claude: Positive language ('honors', 'glorious', 'authentic and contemporary') indicates recommendation, though the brief excerpt limits confidence in the full assessment. | GPT-4o: The review praises the production for honoring the music and addressing the source material's issues, suggesting a positive reception with some acknowledgment of complexity. | Gemini: The review acknowledges the problematic nature of the source material but ultimately praises the production for honoring both the music and the source, suggesting a positive but not unqualified recommendation. | Kimi: The critic praises the production for successfully balancing respect for the original music with a contemporary sensibility, calling it both authentic and glorious despite acknowledging source material issues.
